facts.text: Respondents are alleged to be prostitutes carrying on their trade in the City of Kanpur.
Sub-Inspector of Police, who is a Special Police Officer, gave information to the City Magistrate, Kanpur.

City Magistrate issued notices to respondents under s.20(1) of the Act to show cause why they should not be required to remove themselves from their places of residence and be prohibited from re-entering them.
Respondents received notices and filed objections claiming proceedings were not legally maintainable.
City Magistrate repelled the objections of the respondents.
Respondents filed revisions to Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur, which were dismissed.
Respondents preferred revisions to Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revisions Nos. 322, 323, 324, 611, 612 and 613 of 1961.

Allahabad High Court allowed the revision petitions, set aside proceedings against respondents, and held s.20 abridged fundamental rights under Art.14 and sub-cls. (d) and (e) of Art.19(1) of the Constitution.
High Court granted certificates for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.
State preferred present appeals to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the information received enabling a Magistrate under s.20 to make enquiry should be only from a special police officer designated under s.13 of the Act.
Whether s.20 of the Act offends Art.14 of the Constitution by conferring uncanalized and uncontrolled power on the Magistrate.
Whether s.20 of the Act imposes unreasonable restrictions on the fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(d) and (e) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Information under s.20 may be from any source, not limited to special police officer.
s.20 does not confer uncanalized power; Magistrate acts judicially with procedural safeguards; does not violate Art.14.
Restrictions under s.20 are reasonable in interests of general public and do not violate Art.19(1)(d),(e).

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings not legally maintainable as information not from special police officer.
s.20 confers uncanalized power on Magistrate acting in executive capacity, enables discrimination, violates Art.14.
s.20 abridges fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(d) and (e).

court_reasoning.text: Information under s.20 may be from any source, not limited to special police officer under s.13, as s.20 uses general expression 'on receiving information'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission to specify source indicates any source suffices; distinction from investigation/arrest.

court_reasoning.text: s.20 discloses clear policy with procedural safeguards: Magistrate records info, issues notice with copy, holds inquiry, opportunity to adduce evidence; acts judicially, subject to revision under CrPC ss.435,439; not uncanalized executive power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate of high status functions as court in judicial enquiry.

court_reasoning.text: Classification between prostitutes and non-prostitutes, and between public nuisance prostitutes and others, is reasonable under Art.14; rational relation to object of suppressing immoral traffic and protecting public morals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act's preamble and provisions show policy to suppress traffic, rescue women, prevent moral deterioration.

court_reasoning.text: Restrictions under s.20 reasonable under Art.19(1)(d),(e) in interests of general public; judicial process, policy-based, necessary to control rampant vice of prostitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deportation not excessive if needed for public morals/health; case-specific, revisable.

holdings.text: Information under s.20 may come from any source.
s.20 imposes reasonable restrictions in interests of general public, does not infringe Art.19(1)(d),(e).

precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.20 does not violate Art.14 (agreed); but held deportation unreasonable under Art.19(1)(d),(e) (disagreed).

precedents_cited.case_name: Shama Bai v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Suggested s.20 prima facie offends Art.14 (disagreed).

precedents_cited.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of 'reasonable restrictions': not arbitrary or excessive.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. V.G. Row
precedents_cited.relevance: Test of reasonableness of restrictions: nature of right, purpose, extent of evil, etc.

statutes_cited.name: Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provision for removal/deportation of prostitutes upheld as valid with judicial safeguards.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: s.20 held not to violate equality or freedom of movement/residence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Magistrate acts judicially, subject to revisional jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, reversed Allahabad High Court judgment, held s.20 of the Act constitutional and not violative of Arts.14, 19(1)(d),(e); proceedings against respondents revived implicitly.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside High Court order upholding s.20.

key_quotes.text: The omission is a clear indication that a particular source of information is not material for the application of the section.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds information under s.20 from any source.

key_quotes.text: We therefore, hold that in the circumstances the Magistrate must be held to be acting as a court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes judicial nature of proceedings under s.20.

key_quotes.text: The differences between a woman who is a prostitute and one who is not certainly justify their being placed in different classes.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The said restrictions placed upon them are certainly in the interests of the general public and... the said restrictions are clearly reasonable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
